Lookup3.cc

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*
00002 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00003 lookup3.c, by Bob Jenkins, May 2006, Public Domain.
00004 
00005 These are functions for producing 32-bit hashes for hash table lookup.
00006 hashword(), hashlittle(), hashlittle2(), hashbig(), mix(), and final()
00007 are externally useful functions.  Routines to test the hash are included
00008 if SELF_TEST is defined.  You can use this free for any purpose.  It's in
00009 the public domain.  It has no warranty.
00010 
00011 You probably want to use hashlittle().  hashlittle() and hashbig()
00012 hash byte arrays.  hashlittle() is is faster than hashbig() on
00013 little-endian machines.  Intel and AMD are little-endian machines.
00014 On second thought, you probably want hashlittle2(), which is identical to
00015 hashlittle() except it returns two 32-bit hashes for the price of one.
00016 You could implement hashbig2() if you wanted but I haven't bothered here.
00017 
00018 If you want to find a hash of, say, exactly 7 integers, do
00019   a = i1;  b = i2;  c = i3;
00020   mix(a,b,c);
00021   a += i4; b += i5; c += i6;
00022   mix(a,b,c);
00023   a += i7;
00024   final(a,b,c);
00025 then use c as the hash value.  If you have a variable length array of
00026 4-byte integers to hash, use hashword().  If you have a byte array (like
00027 a character string), use hashlittle().  If you have several byte arrays, or
00028 a mix of things, see the comments above hashlittle().
00029 
00030 Why is this so big?  I read 12 bytes at a time into 3 4-byte integers,
00031 then mix those integers.  This is fast (you can do a lot more thorough
00032 mixing with 12*3 instructions on 3 integers than you can with 3 instructions
00033 on 1 byte), but shoehorning those bytes into integers efficiently is messy.
00034 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00035 */
00036 
00037 //#define SELF_TEST 1
00038 #include "Common/Compat.h"
00039 
00040 #include <stdio.h>      /* defines printf for tests */
00041 #include <time.h>       /* defines time_t for timings in the test */
00042 #include <stdint.h>     /* defines uint32_t etc */
00043 #include <sys/param.h>  /* attempt to define endianness */
00044 #ifdef linux
00045 # include <endian.h>    /* attempt to define endianness */
00046 #endif
00047 
00048 namespace Hypertable {
00049 
00050 /*
00051  * My best guess at if you are big-endian or little-endian.  This may
00052  * need adjustment.
00053  */
00054 #if (defined(__BYTE_ORDER) && defined(__LITTLE_ENDIAN) && \
00055      __BYTE_ORDER == __LITTLE_ENDIAN) || \
00056     (defined(i386) || defined(__i386__) || defined(__i486__) || \
00057      defined(__i586__) || defined(__i686__) || defined(vax) || defined(MIPSEL))
00058 # define HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1
00059 # define HASH_BIG_ENDIAN 0
00060 #elif (defined(__BYTE_ORDER) && defined(__BIG_ENDIAN) && \
00061        __BYTE_ORDER == __BIG_ENDIAN) || \
00062       (defined(sparc) || defined(POWERPC) || defined(mc68000) || defined(sel))
00063 # define HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN 0
00064 # define HASH_BIG_ENDIAN 1
00065 #else
00066 # define HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN 0
00067 # define HASH_BIG_ENDIAN 0
00068 #endif
00069 
00070 #define hashsize(n) ((uint32_t)1<<(n))
00071 #define hashmask(n) (hashsize(n)-1)
00072 #define rot(x,k) (((x)<<(k)) | ((x)>>(32-(k))))
00073 
00074 /*
00075 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00076 mix -- mix 3 32-bit values reversibly.
00077 
00078 This is reversible, so any information in (a,b,c) before mix() is
00079 still in (a,b,c) after mix().
00080 
00081 If four pairs of (a,b,c) inputs are run through mix(), or through
00082 mix() in reverse, there are at least 32 bits of the output that
00083 are sometimes the same for one pair and different for another pair.
00084 This was tested for:
00085 * pairs that differed by one bit, by two bits, in any combination
00086   of top bits of (a,b,c), or in any combination of bottom bits of
00087   (a,b,c).
00088 * "differ" is defined as +, -, ^, or ~^.  For + and -, I transformed
00089   the output delta to a Gray code (a^(a>>1)) so a string of 1's (as
00090   is commonly produced by subtraction) look like a single 1-bit
00091   difference.
00092 * the base values were pseudorandom, all zero but one bit set, or
00093   all zero plus a counter that starts at zero.
00094 
00095 Some k values for my "a-=c; a^=rot(c,k); c+=b;" arrangement that
00096 satisfy this are
00097     4  6  8 16 19  4
00098     9 15  3 18 27 15
00099    14  9  3  7 17  3
00100 Well, "9 15 3 18 27 15" didn't quite get 32 bits diffing
00101 for "differ" defined as + with a one-bit base and a two-bit delta.  I
00102 used http://burtleburtle.net/bob/hash/avalanche.html to choose
00103 the operations, constants, and arrangements of the variables.
00104 
00105 This does not achieve avalanche.  There are input bits of (a,b,c)
00106 that fail to affect some output bits of (a,b,c), especially of a.  The
00107 most thoroughly mixed value is c, but it doesn't really even achieve
00108 avalanche in c.
00109 
00110 This allows some parallelism.  Read-after-writes are good at doubling
00111 the number of bits affected, so the goal of mixing pulls in the opposite
00112 direction as the goal of parallelism.  I did what I could.  Rotates
00113 seem to cost as much as shifts on every machine I could lay my hands
00114 on, and rotates are much kinder to the top and bottom bits, so I used
00115 rotates.
00116 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00117 */
00118 #define mix(a,b,c) \
00119 { \
00120   a -= c;  a ^= rot(c, 4);  c += b; \
00121   b -= a;  b ^= rot(a, 6);  a += c; \
00122   c -= b;  c ^= rot(b, 8);  b += a; \
00123   a -= c;  a ^= rot(c,16);  c += b; \
00124   b -= a;  b ^= rot(a,19);  a += c; \
00125   c -= b;  c ^= rot(b, 4);  b += a; \
00126 }
00127 
00128 /*
00129 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00130 final -- final mixing of 3 32-bit values (a,b,c) into c
00131 
00132 Pairs of (a,b,c) values differing in only a few bits will usually
00133 produce values of c that look totally different.  This was tested for
00134 * pairs that differed by one bit, by two bits, in any combination
00135   of top bits of (a,b,c), or in any combination of bottom bits of
00136   (a,b,c).
00137 * "differ" is defined as +, -, ^, or ~^.  For + and -, I transformed
00138   the output delta to a Gray code (a^(a>>1)) so a string of 1's (as
00139   is commonly produced by subtraction) look like a single 1-bit
00140   difference.
00141 * the base values were pseudorandom, all zero but one bit set, or
00142   all zero plus a counter that starts at zero.
00143 
00144 These constants passed:
00145  14 11 25 16 4 14 24
00146  12 14 25 16 4 14 24
00147 and these came close:
00148   4  8 15 26 3 22 24
00149  10  8 15 26 3 22 24
00150  11  8 15 26 3 22 24
00151 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00152 */
00153 #define final(a,b,c) \
00154 { \
00155   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,14); \
00156   a ^= c; a -= rot(c,11); \
00157   b ^= a; b -= rot(a,25); \
00158   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,16); \
00159   a ^= c; a -= rot(c,4);  \
00160   b ^= a; b -= rot(a,14); \
00161   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,24); \
00162 }
00163 
00164 /*
00165 --------------------------------------------------------------------
00166  This works on all machines.  To be useful, it requires
00167  -- that the key be an array of uint32_t's, and
00168  -- that the length be the number of uint32_t's in the key
00169 
00170  The function hashword() is identical to hashlittle() on little-endian
00171  machines, and identical to hashbig() on big-endian machines,
00172  except that the length has to be measured in uint32_ts rather than in
00173  bytes.  hashlittle() is more complicated than hashword() only because
00174  hashlittle() has to dance around fitting the key bytes into registers.
00175 --------------------------------------------------------------------
00176 */
00177 uint32_t hashword(
00178 const uint32_t *k,                   /* the key, an array of uint32_t values */
00179 size_t          length,               /* the length of the key, in uint32_ts */
00180 uint32_t        initval)         /* the previous hash, or an arbitrary value */
00181 {
00182   uint32_t a,b,c;
00183 
00184   /* Set up the internal state */
00185   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + (((uint32_t)length)<<2) + initval;
00186 
00187   /*------------------------------------------------- handle most of the key */
00188   while (length > 3)
00189   {
00190     a += k[0];
00191     b += k[1];
00192     c += k[2];
00193     mix(a,b,c);
00194     length -= 3;
00195     k += 3;
00196   }
00197 
00198   /*------------------------------------------- handle the last 3 uint32_t's */
00199   switch(length)                     /* all the case statements fall through */
00200   {
00201   case 3 : c+=k[2];
00202   case 2 : b+=k[1];
00203   case 1 : a+=k[0];
00204     final(a,b,c);
00205   case 0:     /* case 0: nothing left to add */
00206     break;
00207   }
00208   /*------------------------------------------------------ report the result */
00209   return c;
00210 }
00211 
00212 
00213 /*
00214 --------------------------------------------------------------------
00215 hashword2() -- same as hashword(), but take two seeds and return two
00216 32-bit values.  pc and pb must both be nonnull, and *pc and *pb must
00217 both be initialized with seeds.  If you pass in (*pb)==0, the output
00218 (*pc) will be the same as the return value from hashword().
00219 --------------------------------------------------------------------
00220 */
00221 void hashword2 (
00222 const uint32_t *k,                   /* the key, an array of uint32_t values */
00223 size_t          length,               /* the length of the key, in uint32_ts */
00224 uint32_t       *pc,                      /* IN: seed OUT: primary hash value */
00225 uint32_t       *pb)               /* IN: more seed OUT: secondary hash value */
00226 {
00227   uint32_t a,b,c;
00228 
00229   /* Set up the internal state */
00230   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + ((uint32_t)(length<<2)) + *pc;
00231   c += *pb;
00232 
00233   /*------------------------------------------------- handle most of the key */
00234   while (length > 3)
00235   {
00236     a += k[0];
00237     b += k[1];
00238     c += k[2];
00239     mix(a,b,c);
00240     length -= 3;
00241     k += 3;
00242   }
00243 
00244   /*------------------------------------------- handle the last 3 uint32_t's */
00245   switch(length)                     /* all the case statements fall through */
00246   {
00247   case 3 : c+=k[2];
00248   case 2 : b+=k[1];
00249   case 1 : a+=k[0];
00250     final(a,b,c);
00251   case 0:     /* case 0: nothing left to add */
00252     break;
00253   }
00254   /*------------------------------------------------------ report the result */
00255   *pc=c; *pb=b;
00256 }
00257 
00258 
00259 /*
00260 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00261 hashlittle() -- hash a variable-length key into a 32-bit value
00262   k       : the key (the unaligned variable-length array of bytes)
00263   length  : the length of the key, counting by bytes
00264   initval : can be any 4-byte value
00265 Returns a 32-bit value.  Every bit of the key affects every bit of
00266 the return value.  Two keys differing by one or two bits will have
00267 totally different hash values.
00268 
00269 The best hash table sizes are powers of 2.  There is no need to do
00270 mod a prime (mod is sooo slow!).  If you need less than 32 bits,
00271 use a bitmask.  For example, if you need only 10 bits, do
00272   h = (h & hashmask(10));
00273 In which case, the hash table should have hashsize(10) elements.
00274 
00275 If you are hashing n strings (uint8_t **)k, do it like this:
00276   for (i=0, h=0; i<n; ++i) h = hashlittle( k[i], len[i], h);
00277 
00278 By Bob Jenkins, 2006.  bob_jenkins@burtleburtle.net.  You may use this
00279 code any way you wish, private, educational, or commercial.  It's free.
00280 
00281 Use for hash table lookup, or anything where one collision in 2^^32 is
00282 acceptable.  Do NOT use for cryptographic purposes.
00283 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00284 */
00285 
00286 uint32_t hashlittle( const void *key, size_t length, uint32_t initval)
00287 {
00288   uint32_t a,b,c;                                          /* internal state */
00289   union { const void *ptr; size_t i; } u;     /* needed for Mac Powerbook G4 */
00290 
00291   /* Set up the internal state */
00292   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + ((uint32_t)length) + initval;
00293 
00294   u.ptr = key;
00295   if (HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN && ((u.i & 0x3) == 0)) {
00296     const uint32_t *k = (const uint32_t *)key;         /* read 32-bit chunks */
00297     const uint8_t  *k8; HT_UNUSED(k8);
00298 
00299     /*------ all but last block: aligned reads and affect 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00300     while (length > 12)
00301     {
00302       a += k[0];
00303       b += k[1];
00304       c += k[2];
00305       mix(a,b,c);
00306       length -= 12;
00307       k += 3;
00308     }
00309 
00310     /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00311     /*
00312      * "k[2]&0xffffff" actually reads beyond the end of the string, but
00313      * then masks off the part it's not allowed to read.  Because the
00314      * string is aligned, the masked-off tail is in the same word as the
00315      * rest of the string.  Every machine with memory protection I've seen
00316      * does it on word boundaries, so is OK with this.  But VALGRIND will
00317      * still catch it and complain.  The masking trick does make the hash
00318      * noticably faster for short strings (like English words).
00319      */
00320 #ifndef VALGRIND
00321 
00322     switch(length)
00323     {
00324     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00325     case 11: c+=k[2]&0xffffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00326     case 10: c+=k[2]&0xffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00327     case 9 : c+=k[2]&0xff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00328     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00329     case 7 : b+=k[1]&0xffffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00330     case 6 : b+=k[1]&0xffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00331     case 5 : b+=k[1]&0xff; a+=k[0]; break;
00332     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00333     case 3 : a+=k[0]&0xffffff; break;
00334     case 2 : a+=k[0]&0xffff; break;
00335     case 1 : a+=k[0]&0xff; break;
00336     case 0 : return c;              /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00337     }
00338 
00339 #else /* make valgrind happy */
00340 
00341     k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00342     switch(length)
00343     {
00344     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00345     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<16;  /* fall through */
00346     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k8[9])<<8;    /* fall through */
00347     case 9 : c+=k8[8];                   /* fall through */
00348     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00349     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<16;   /* fall through */
00350     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[5])<<8;    /* fall through */
00351     case 5 : b+=k8[4];                   /* fall through */
00352     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00353     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<16;   /* fall through */
00354     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[1])<<8;    /* fall through */
00355     case 1 : a+=k8[0]; break;
00356     case 0 : return c;
00357     }
00358 
00359 #endif /* !valgrind */
00360 
00361   } else if (HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN && ((u.i & 0x1) == 0)) {
00362     const uint16_t *k = (const uint16_t *)key;         /* read 16-bit chunks */
00363     const uint8_t  *k8;
00364 
00365     /*--------------- all but last block: aligned reads and different mixing */
00366     while (length > 12)
00367     {
00368       a += k[0] + (((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00369       b += k[2] + (((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00370       c += k[4] + (((uint32_t)k[5])<<16);
00371       mix(a,b,c);
00372       length -= 12;
00373       k += 6;
00374     }
00375 
00376     /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00377     k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00378     switch(length)
00379     {
00380     case 12: c+=k[4]+(((uint32_t)k[5])<<16);
00381              b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00382              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00383              break;
00384     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<16;     /* fall through */
00385     case 10: c+=k[4];
00386              b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00387              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00388              break;
00389     case 9 : c+=k8[8];                      /* fall through */
00390     case 8 : b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00391              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00392              break;
00393     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<16;      /* fall through */
00394     case 6 : b+=k[2];
00395              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00396              break;
00397     case 5 : b+=k8[4];                      /* fall through */
00398     case 4 : a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00399              break;
00400     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<16;      /* fall through */
00401     case 2 : a+=k[0];
00402              break;
00403     case 1 : a+=k8[0];
00404              break;
00405     case 0 : return c;                     /* zero length requires no mixing */
00406     }
00407 
00408   } else {                        /* need to read the key one byte at a time */
00409     const uint8_t *k = (const uint8_t *)key;
00410 
00411     /*--------------- all but the last block: affect some 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00412     while (length > 12)
00413     {
00414       a += k[0];
00415       a += ((uint32_t)k[1])<<8;
00416       a += ((uint32_t)k[2])<<16;
00417       a += ((uint32_t)k[3])<<24;
00418       b += k[4];
00419       b += ((uint32_t)k[5])<<8;
00420       b += ((uint32_t)k[6])<<16;
00421       b += ((uint32_t)k[7])<<24;
00422       c += k[8];
00423       c += ((uint32_t)k[9])<<8;
00424       c += ((uint32_t)k[10])<<16;
00425       c += ((uint32_t)k[11])<<24;
00426       mix(a,b,c);
00427       length -= 12;
00428       k += 12;
00429     }
00430 
00431     /*-------------------------------- last block: affect all 32 bits of (c) */
00432     switch(length)                   /* all the case statements fall through */
00433     {
00434     case 12: c+=((uint32_t)k[11])<<24;
00435     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k[10])<<16;
00436     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k[9])<<8;
00437     case 9 : c+=k[8];
00438     case 8 : b+=((uint32_t)k[7])<<24;
00439     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k[6])<<16;
00440     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k[5])<<8;
00441     case 5 : b+=k[4];
00442     case 4 : a+=((uint32_t)k[3])<<24;
00443     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k[2])<<16;
00444     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k[1])<<8;
00445     case 1 : a+=k[0];
00446              break;
00447     case 0 : return c;
00448     }
00449   }
00450 
00451   final(a,b,c);
00452   return c;
00453 }
00454 
00455 
00456 /*
00457  * hashlittle2: return 2 32-bit hash values
00458  *
00459  * This is identical to hashlittle(), except it returns two 32-bit hash
00460  * values instead of just one.  This is good enough for hash table
00461  * lookup with 2^^64 buckets, or if you want a second hash if you're not
00462  * happy with the first, or if you want a probably-unique 64-bit ID for
00463  * the key.  *pc is better mixed than *pb, so use *pc first.  If you want
00464  * a 64-bit value do something like "*pc + (((uint64_t)*pb)<<32)".
00465  */
00466 void hashlittle2(
00467   const void *key,       /* the key to hash */
00468   size_t      length,    /* length of the key */
00469   uint32_t   *pc,        /* IN: primary initval, OUT: primary hash */
00470   uint32_t   *pb)        /* IN: secondary initval, OUT: secondary hash */
00471 {
00472   uint32_t a,b,c;                                          /* internal state */
00473   union { const void *ptr; size_t i; } u;     /* needed for Mac Powerbook G4 */
00474 
00475   /* Set up the internal state */
00476   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + ((uint32_t)length) + *pc;
00477   c += *pb;
00478 
00479   u.ptr = key;
00480   if (HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN && ((u.i & 0x3) == 0)) {
00481     const uint32_t *k = (const uint32_t *)key;         /* read 32-bit chunks */
00482     const uint8_t  *k8; HT_UNUSED(k8);
00483 
00484     /*------ all but last block: aligned reads and affect 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00485     while (length > 12)
00486     {
00487       a += k[0];
00488       b += k[1];
00489       c += k[2];
00490       mix(a,b,c);
00491       length -= 12;
00492       k += 3;
00493     }
00494 
00495     /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00496     /*
00497      * "k[2]&0xffffff" actually reads beyond the end of the string, but
00498      * then masks off the part it's not allowed to read.  Because the
00499      * string is aligned, the masked-off tail is in the same word as the
00500      * rest of the string.  Every machine with memory protection I've seen
00501      * does it on word boundaries, so is OK with this.  But VALGRIND will
00502      * still catch it and complain.  The masking trick does make the hash
00503      * noticably faster for short strings (like English words).
00504      */
00505 #ifndef VALGRIND
00506 
00507     switch(length)
00508     {
00509     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00510     case 11: c+=k[2]&0xffffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00511     case 10: c+=k[2]&0xffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00512     case 9 : c+=k[2]&0xff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00513     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00514     case 7 : b+=k[1]&0xffffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00515     case 6 : b+=k[1]&0xffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00516     case 5 : b+=k[1]&0xff; a+=k[0]; break;
00517     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00518     case 3 : a+=k[0]&0xffffff; break;
00519     case 2 : a+=k[0]&0xffff; break;
00520     case 1 : a+=k[0]&0xff; break;
00521     case 0 : *pc=c; *pb=b; return;  /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00522     }
00523 
00524 #else /* make valgrind happy */
00525 
00526     k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00527     switch(length)
00528     {
00529     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00530     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<16;  /* fall through */
00531     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k8[9])<<8;    /* fall through */
00532     case 9 : c+=k8[8];                   /* fall through */
00533     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00534     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<16;   /* fall through */
00535     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[5])<<8;    /* fall through */
00536     case 5 : b+=k8[4];                   /* fall through */
00537     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00538     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<16;   /* fall through */
00539     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[1])<<8;    /* fall through */
00540     case 1 : a+=k8[0]; break;
00541     case 0 : *pc=c; *pb=b; return;  /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00542     }
00543 
00544 #endif /* !valgrind */
00545 
00546   } else if (HASH_LITTLE_ENDIAN && ((u.i & 0x1) == 0)) {
00547     const uint16_t *k = (const uint16_t *)key;         /* read 16-bit chunks */
00548     const uint8_t  *k8;
00549 
00550     /*--------------- all but last block: aligned reads and different mixing */
00551     while (length > 12)
00552     {
00553       a += k[0] + (((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00554       b += k[2] + (((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00555       c += k[4] + (((uint32_t)k[5])<<16);
00556       mix(a,b,c);
00557       length -= 12;
00558       k += 6;
00559     }
00560 
00561     /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00562     k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00563     switch(length)
00564     {
00565     case 12: c+=k[4]+(((uint32_t)k[5])<<16);
00566              b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00567              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00568              break;
00569     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<16;     /* fall through */
00570     case 10: c+=k[4];
00571              b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00572              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00573              break;
00574     case 9 : c+=k8[8];                      /* fall through */
00575     case 8 : b+=k[2]+(((uint32_t)k[3])<<16);
00576              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00577              break;
00578     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<16;      /* fall through */
00579     case 6 : b+=k[2];
00580              a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00581              break;
00582     case 5 : b+=k8[4];                      /* fall through */
00583     case 4 : a+=k[0]+(((uint32_t)k[1])<<16);
00584              break;
00585     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<16;      /* fall through */
00586     case 2 : a+=k[0];
00587              break;
00588     case 1 : a+=k8[0];
00589              break;
00590     case 0 : *pc=c; *pb=b; return;  /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00591     }
00592 
00593   } else {                        /* need to read the key one byte at a time */
00594     const uint8_t *k = (const uint8_t *)key;
00595 
00596     /*--------------- all but the last block: affect some 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00597     while (length > 12)
00598     {
00599       a += k[0];
00600       a += ((uint32_t)k[1])<<8;
00601       a += ((uint32_t)k[2])<<16;
00602       a += ((uint32_t)k[3])<<24;
00603       b += k[4];
00604       b += ((uint32_t)k[5])<<8;
00605       b += ((uint32_t)k[6])<<16;
00606       b += ((uint32_t)k[7])<<24;
00607       c += k[8];
00608       c += ((uint32_t)k[9])<<8;
00609       c += ((uint32_t)k[10])<<16;
00610       c += ((uint32_t)k[11])<<24;
00611       mix(a,b,c);
00612       length -= 12;
00613       k += 12;
00614     }
00615 
00616     /*-------------------------------- last block: affect all 32 bits of (c) */
00617     switch(length)                   /* all the case statements fall through */
00618     {
00619     case 12: c+=((uint32_t)k[11])<<24;
00620     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k[10])<<16;
00621     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k[9])<<8;
00622     case 9 : c+=k[8];
00623     case 8 : b+=((uint32_t)k[7])<<24;
00624     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k[6])<<16;
00625     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k[5])<<8;
00626     case 5 : b+=k[4];
00627     case 4 : a+=((uint32_t)k[3])<<24;
00628     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k[2])<<16;
00629     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k[1])<<8;
00630     case 1 : a+=k[0];
00631              break;
00632     case 0 : *pc=c; *pb=b; return;  /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00633     }
00634   }
00635 
00636   final(a,b,c);
00637   *pc=c; *pb=b;
00638 }
00639 
00640 
00641 
00642 /*
00643  * hashbig():
00644  * This is the same as hashword() on big-endian machines.  It is different
00645  * from hashlittle() on all machines.  hashbig() takes advantage of
00646  * big-endian byte ordering.
00647  */
00648 uint32_t hashbig( const void *key, size_t length, uint32_t initval)
00649 {
00650   uint32_t a,b,c;
00651   union { const void *ptr; size_t i; } u; /* to cast key to (size_t) happily */
00652 
00653   /* Set up the internal state */
00654   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + ((uint32_t)length) + initval;
00655 
00656   u.ptr = key;
00657   if (HASH_BIG_ENDIAN && ((u.i & 0x3) == 0)) {
00658     const uint32_t *k = (const uint32_t *)key;         /* read 32-bit chunks */
00659     const uint8_t  *k8; HT_UNUSED(k8);
00660 
00661     /*------ all but last block: aligned reads and affect 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00662     while (length > 12)
00663     {
00664       a += k[0];
00665       b += k[1];
00666       c += k[2];
00667       mix(a,b,c);
00668       length -= 12;
00669       k += 3;
00670     }
00671 
00672     /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00673     /*
00674      * "k[2]<<8" actually reads beyond the end of the string, but
00675      * then shifts out the part it's not allowed to read.  Because the
00676      * string is aligned, the illegal read is in the same word as the
00677      * rest of the string.  Every machine with memory protection I've seen
00678      * does it on word boundaries, so is OK with this.  But VALGRIND will
00679      * still catch it and complain.  The masking trick does make the hash
00680      * noticably faster for short strings (like English words).
00681      */
00682 #ifndef VALGRIND
00683 
00684     switch(length)
00685     {
00686     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00687     case 11: c+=k[2]&0xffffff00; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00688     case 10: c+=k[2]&0xffff0000; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00689     case 9 : c+=k[2]&0xff000000; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00690     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00691     case 7 : b+=k[1]&0xffffff00; a+=k[0]; break;
00692     case 6 : b+=k[1]&0xffff0000; a+=k[0]; break;
00693     case 5 : b+=k[1]&0xff000000; a+=k[0]; break;
00694     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00695     case 3 : a+=k[0]&0xffffff00; break;
00696     case 2 : a+=k[0]&0xffff0000; break;
00697     case 1 : a+=k[0]&0xff000000; break;
00698     case 0 : return c;              /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00699     }
00700 
00701 #else  /* make valgrind happy */
00702 
00703     k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00704     switch(length)                   /* all the case statements fall through */
00705     {
00706     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00707     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<8;  /* fall through */
00708     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k8[9])<<16;  /* fall through */
00709     case 9 : c+=((uint32_t)k8[8])<<24;  /* fall through */
00710     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00711     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<8;   /* fall through */
00712     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[5])<<16;  /* fall through */
00713     case 5 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[4])<<24;  /* fall through */
00714     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00715     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<8;   /* fall through */
00716     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[1])<<16;  /* fall through */
00717     case 1 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[0])<<24; break;
00718     case 0 : return c;
00719     }
00720 
00721 #endif /* !VALGRIND */
00722 
00723   } else {                        /* need to read the key one byte at a time */
00724     const uint8_t *k = (const uint8_t *)key;
00725 
00726     /*--------------- all but the last block: affect some 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00727     while (length > 12)
00728     {
00729       a += ((uint32_t)k[0])<<24;
00730       a += ((uint32_t)k[1])<<16;
00731       a += ((uint32_t)k[2])<<8;
00732       a += ((uint32_t)k[3]);
00733       b += ((uint32_t)k[4])<<24;
00734       b += ((uint32_t)k[5])<<16;
00735       b += ((uint32_t)k[6])<<8;
00736       b += ((uint32_t)k[7]);
00737       c += ((uint32_t)k[8])<<24;
00738       c += ((uint32_t)k[9])<<16;
00739       c += ((uint32_t)k[10])<<8;
00740       c += ((uint32_t)k[11]);
00741       mix(a,b,c);
00742       length -= 12;
00743       k += 12;
00744     }
00745 
00746     /*-------------------------------- last block: affect all 32 bits of (c) */
00747     switch(length)                   /* all the case statements fall through */
00748     {
00749     case 12: c+=k[11];
00750     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k[10])<<8;
00751     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k[9])<<16;
00752     case 9 : c+=((uint32_t)k[8])<<24;
00753     case 8 : b+=k[7];
00754     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k[6])<<8;
00755     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k[5])<<16;
00756     case 5 : b+=((uint32_t)k[4])<<24;
00757     case 4 : a+=k[3];
00758     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k[2])<<8;
00759     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k[1])<<16;
00760     case 1 : a+=((uint32_t)k[0])<<24;
00761              break;
00762     case 0 : return c;
00763     }
00764   }
00765 
00766   final(a,b,c);
00767   return c;
00768 }
00769 
00770 } // namespace Hypertable
00771 
00772 #ifdef SELF_TEST
00773 
00774 /* used for timings */
00775 void driver1()
00776 {
00777   uint8_t buf[256];
00778   uint32_t i;
00779   uint32_t h=0;
00780   time_t a,z;
00781 
00782   time(&a);
00783   for (i=0; i<256; ++i) buf[i] = 'x';
00784   for (i=0; i<1; ++i)
00785   {
00786     h = hashlittle(&buf[0],1,h);
00787   }
00788   time(&z);
00789   if (z-a > 0) printf("time %d %.8x\n", z-a, h);
00790 }
00791 
00792 /* check that every input bit changes every output bit half the time */
00793 #define HASHSTATE 1
00794 #define HASHLEN   1
00795 #define MAXPAIR 60
00796 #define MAXLEN  70
00797 void driver2()
00798 {
00799   uint8_t qa[MAXLEN+1], qb[MAXLEN+2], *a = &qa[0], *b = &qb[1];
00800   uint32_t c[HASHSTATE], d[HASHSTATE], i=0, j=0, k, l, m=0, z;
00801   uint32_t e[HASHSTATE],f[HASHSTATE],g[HASHSTATE],h[HASHSTATE];
00802   uint32_t x[HASHSTATE],y[HASHSTATE];
00803   uint32_t hlen;
00804 
00805   printf("No more than %d trials should ever be needed \n",MAXPAIR/2);
00806   for (hlen=0; hlen < MAXLEN; ++hlen)
00807   {
00808     z=0;
00809     for (i=0; i<hlen; ++i)  /*----------------------- for each input byte, */
00810     {
00811       for (j=0; j<8; ++j)   /*------------------------ for each input bit, */
00812       {
00813         for (m=1; m<8; ++m) /*------------ for serveral possible initvals, */
00814         {
00815           for (l=0; l<HASHSTATE; ++l)
00816             e[l]=f[l]=g[l]=h[l]=x[l]=y[l]=~((uint32_t)0);
00817 
00818           /*---- check that every output bit is affected by that input bit */
00819           for (k=0; k<MAXPAIR; k+=2)
00820           {
00821             uint32_t finished=1;
00822             /* keys have one bit different */
00823             for (l=0; l<hlen+1; ++l) {a[l] = b[l] = (uint8_t)0;}
00824             /* have a and b be two keys differing in only one bit */
00825             a[i] ^= (k<<j);
00826             a[i] ^= (k>>(8-j));
00827              c[0] = hashlittle(a, hlen, m);
00828             b[i] ^= ((k+1)<<j);
00829             b[i] ^= ((k+1)>>(8-j));
00830              d[0] = hashlittle(b, hlen, m);
00831             /* check every bit is 1, 0, set, and not set at least once */
00832             for (l=0; l<HASHSTATE; ++l)
00833             {
00834               e[l] &= (c[l]^d[l]);
00835               f[l] &= ~(c[l]^d[l]);
00836               g[l] &= c[l];
00837               h[l] &= ~c[l];
00838               x[l] &= d[l];
00839               y[l] &= ~d[l];
00840               if (e[l]|f[l]|g[l]|h[l]|x[l]|y[l]) finished=0;
00841             }
00842             if (finished) break;
00843           }
00844           if (k>z) z=k;
00845           if (k==MAXPAIR)
00846           {
00847              printf("Some bit didn't change: ");
00848              printf("%.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x  ",
00849                     e[0],f[0],g[0],h[0],x[0],y[0]);
00850              printf("i %d j %d m %d len %d\n", i, j, m, hlen);
00851           }
00852           if (z==MAXPAIR) goto done;
00853         }
00854       }
00855     }
00856    done:
00857     if (z < MAXPAIR)
00858     {
00859       printf("Mix success  %2d bytes  %2d initvals  ",i,m);
00860       printf("required  %d  trials\n", z/2);
00861     }
00862   }
00863   printf("\n");
00864 }
00865 
00866 /* Check for reading beyond the end of the buffer and alignment problems */
00867 void driver3()
00868 {
00869   uint8_t buf[MAXLEN+20], *b;
00870   uint32_t len;
00871   uint8_t q[] = "This is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country...";
00872   uint32_t h;
00873   uint8_t qq[] = "xThis is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country...";
00874   uint32_t i;
00875   uint8_t qqq[] = "xxThis is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country...";
00876   uint32_t j;
00877   uint8_t qqqq[] = "xxxThis is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country...";
00878   uint32_t ref,x,y;
00879   uint8_t *p;
00880 
00881   printf("Endianness.  These lines should all be the same (for values filled in):\n");
00882   printf("%.8x                            %.8x                            %.8x\n",
00883          hashword((const uint32_t *)q, (sizeof(q)-1)/4, 13),
00884          hashword((const uint32_t *)q, (sizeof(q)-5)/4, 13),
00885          hashword((const uint32_t *)q, (sizeof(q)-9)/4, 13));
00886   p = q;
00887   printf("%.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x\n",
00888          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-1, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-2, 13),
00889          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-3, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-4, 13),
00890          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-5, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-6, 13),
00891          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-7, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-8, 13),
00892          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-9, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-10, 13),
00893          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-11, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-12, 13));
00894   p = &qq[1];
00895   printf("%.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x\n",
00896          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-1, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-2, 13),
00897          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-3, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-4, 13),
00898          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-5, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-6, 13),
00899          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-7, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-8, 13),
00900          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-9, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-10, 13),
00901          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-11, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-12, 13));
00902   p = &qqq[2];
00903   printf("%.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x\n",
00904          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-1, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-2, 13),
00905          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-3, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-4, 13),
00906          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-5, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-6, 13),
00907          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-7, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-8, 13),
00908          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-9, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-10, 13),
00909          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-11, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-12, 13));
00910   p = &qqqq[3];
00911   printf("%.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x %.8x\n",
00912          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-1, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-2, 13),
00913          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-3, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-4, 13),
00914          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-5, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-6, 13),
00915          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-7, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-8, 13),
00916          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-9, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-10, 13),
00917          hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-11, 13), hashlittle(p, sizeof(q)-12, 13));
00918   printf("\n");
00919 
00920   /* check that hashlittle2 and hashlittle produce the same results */
00921   i=47; j=0;
00922   hashlittle2(q, sizeof(q), &i, &j);
00923   if (hashlittle(q, sizeof(q), 47) != i)
00924     printf("hashlittle2 and hashlittle mismatch\n");
00925 
00926   /* check that hashword2 and hashword produce the same results */
00927   len = 0xdeadbeef;
00928   i=47, j=0;
00929   hashword2(&len, 1, &i, &j);
00930   if (hashword(&len, 1, 47) != i)
00931     printf("hashword2 and hashword mismatch %x %x\n",
00932            i, hashword(&len, 1, 47));
00933 
00934   /* check hashlittle doesn't read before or after the ends of the string */
00935   for (h=0, b=buf+1; h<8; ++h, ++b)
00936   {
00937     for (i=0; i<MAXLEN; ++i)
00938     {
00939       len = i;
00940       for (j=0; j<i; ++j) *(b+j)=0;
00941 
00942       /* these should all be equal */
00943       ref = hashlittle(b, len, (uint32_t)1);
00944       *(b+i)=(uint8_t)~0;
00945       *(b-1)=(uint8_t)~0;
00946       x = hashlittle(b, len, (uint32_t)1);
00947       y = hashlittle(b, len, (uint32_t)1);
00948       if ((ref != x) || (ref != y))
00949       {
00950         printf("alignment error: %.8x %.8x %.8x %d %d\n",ref,x,y,
00951                h, i);
00952       }
00953     }
00954   }
00955 }
00956 
00957 /* check for problems with nulls */
00958  void driver4()
00959 {
00960   uint8_t buf[1];
00961   uint32_t h,i,state[HASHSTATE];
00962 
00963 
00964   buf[0] = ~0;
00965   for (i=0; i<HASHSTATE; ++i) state[i] = 1;
00966   printf("These should all be different\n");
00967   for (i=0, h=0; i<8; ++i)
00968   {
00969     h = hashlittle(buf, 0, h);
00970     printf("%2ld  0-byte strings, hash is  %.8x\n", i, h);
00971   }
00972 }
00973 
00974 void driver5()
00975 {
00976   uint32_t b,c;
00977   b=0, c=0, hashlittle2("", 0, &c, &b);
00978   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* deadbeef deadbeef */
00979   b=0xdeadbeef, c=0, hashlittle2("", 0, &c, &b);
00980   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* bd5b7dde deadbeef */
00981   b=0xdeadbeef, c=0xdeadbeef, hashlittle2("", 0, &c, &b);
00982   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* 9c093ccd bd5b7dde */
00983   b=0, c=0, hashlittle2("Four score and seven years ago", 30, &c, &b);
00984   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* 17770551 ce7226e6 */
00985   b=1, c=0, hashlittle2("Four score and seven years ago", 30, &c, &b);
00986   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* e3607cae bd371de4 */
00987   b=0, c=1, hashlittle2("Four score and seven years ago", 30, &c, &b);
00988   printf("hash is %.8lx %.8lx\n", c, b);   /* cd628161 6cbea4b3 */
00989   c = hashlittle("Four score and seven years ago", 30, 0);
00990   printf("hash is %.8lx\n", c);   /* 17770551 */
00991   c = hashlittle("Four score and seven years ago", 30, 1);
00992   printf("hash is %.8lx\n", c);   /* cd628161 */
00993 }
00994 
00995 
00996 int main()
00997 {
00998   driver1();   /* test that the key is hashed: used for timings */
00999   driver2();   /* test that whole key is hashed thoroughly */
01000   driver3();   /* test that nothing but the key is hashed */
01001   driver4();   /* test hashing multiple buffers (all buffers are null) */
